turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello, hi, I'm Doctor Jacob and welcome to Babylon. Hello.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> Nice to meet you too. So just before we start, is it all right if you could confirm your name for me please?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and your address for me please.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Two three one, Leonard, London <UNSURE>street</UNSURE> uh, sorry, London.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK and that's correct, and just to confirm that you're in a secure location and we can have a confidential conversation.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, uh, you've mentioned on our notes that you're suffering from bad diarrhea. I'm sorry to hear about it. So if you tell me a bit more about it, please.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, it's been happening for about, three days now? Um, yeah it, started off uh, was, I don't know <UNSURE>it's</UNSURE> just something that I thought would go away pretty quickly.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> I've had that from time to time after eating certain types of food or going on certain travels, <UNSURE>but</UNSURE>, uh nothing funky in my diet <UNSURE>and</UNSURE> no travels recently, um and it just kinda kept up. I'm a bit confused as to what to do <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So you <UNSURE>haven't</UNSURE> had anything from outside? Nothing dodgy anything <UNIN/>? No.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no no no, just a little bit, yeah I I don't know I mean it's pretty standard diarrhoea, where it's was like a little bit of abdominal pain. I threw up once, <UNIN/> that <UNSURE>was a</UNSURE> little worrying, uh.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Repeat that please, that wasn't clear. What did you say?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, right, and with the diarrhea, how many times a day are you going to the toilet?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Four to five times, yeah. And is there any? And it's like water? Is it like water or is it just loose?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you going like water? Or is it just, you know bit, bit of <UNIN/> solid stools, bit loose kind of thing?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It probably depends on the time of day to be honest, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Sure</UNSURE> OK. Bit of both and is there any blood or mucus?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No blood. What do you mean mucus?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, so no mucus, OK. Any fever at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, maybe a little bit, but.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It hasn't been, that in particular hasn't been too worrying.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you still able to eat, and drink?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Appetite loss I guess <UNSURE>worse</UNSURE> than normal, <UNIN/> but also not something I've, like I, if that was alone I wouldn't have, reached out.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sure. So but you're you're still able to drink quite a bit yeah? You're drinking plenty.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and, um, what have you take, have you taken anything so far for the diarrhea?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Nothing yet, OK. Anything for the abdominal pain?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Right, and any <UNIN/> unfortunately we don't have any of your past medical history, is there anything you'd like to say?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um or, or I don't know I guess I still have it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK and uh, are you, any, uh, anything else other than asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Has hypertension. <UNSURE>Had</UNSURE> hypertension. <UNIN/> Yeah he died of bowel cancer ten years ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ohh dear, OK. Bowel cancer. Ten years ago. And how old was he when he died?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: K, and um, you mentioned you had asthma, are you using any inhalers at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, not heard of it may. Is it <UNSURE>like</UNSURE> Salbutamol? Is it like a blue colour?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yellow, OK. I'll have to check that one, not sure. <UNSURE>Laxepro</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, that's fine. Any other medication that you're using?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> Over the counter, anything at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No allergies at all, righty <UNIN/>. Fine so, obviously, you know you just have diarrhea it's about four to five times a day. Um, you're still drinking plenty and you look like you're not dehydrated which is a good sign, OK? Um, when we start worrying about diarrhea is if you're going more than eight times a day.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That means probably you are, you know, whatever you're eating is going straight through, OK? You still need to drink plenty of water because you're losing a lot of fluids.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, when you go to the toilet. Um, things that one would advise is a soft diet. So avoid dairy, fish, meat, eggs, while you're having the diarrhea. <UNSURE>Go</UNSURE>, sorry?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: What is a soft diet? What does that <UNIN/>? Like, outside of, not those things, what do you mean by soft?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, so that will be like crackers, toast, jam, those kind of things that's easily digested. Like what we <UNSURE>are good</UNSURE> give babies yeah. When they start eating you give, simple food for babies. You don't give eggs or meat the first time they start feeding. So that's the kind of soft diet we're talking about, yeah? Once you are able to, you know keep most of it in, you can start off with some just boiled vegetables and mash.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Once you're OK with that for about forty-eight hours then you can start having meat. So just don't have meat <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> <UNSURE>once</UNSURE> you feel like you're slightly better, because you might go back to square one again, all <UNSURE>right</UNSURE>?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: What <UNSURE>do you mean</UNSURE> OK with that diet, like once?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> Forty-eight hours you're not having any diarrhea, you're fine then you can go and start having meat, egg, fish and <UNSURE>all</UNSURE>. So that <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>, <UNIN/> <UNSURE>if if the diarrhoea</UNSURE> is getting better but isn't getting, or do you want it to go away completely at that point, or if it's like <UNSURE>trending upwards</UNSURE>?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, no, no <UNIN/> preferably just don't because, what why do we say this? It's because it takes much more time for meat to get digested. So because your gut flora, you know, the, the, the bacteria in your gut is not you know as it should be, it takes a bit more effort for one to digest these food.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: While it doesn't take that much of an effort to, you know digest mash and vegetables. Does that make sense?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah? So, um, at the same time you could have some, although you can't <UNIN/> milk is not a good idea, yoghurts are a good idea because they <UNSURE>are</UNSURE> probiotics, it help to build up the normal, um gut, gut bacteria back.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So those kinda, now, things to look out for, if your diarrhoea doesn't go away in a week's time, or if you're passing blood, we need a stool sample, because that means you <UNIN/> you may have <UNIN/>, um, some particular bugs that might need treatment with antibiotics.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. If you're again, as I've mentioned previously if you're going about six to eight times a day, that means there's a high chance that, uh, you are, having <UNIN/> dehydration and you might need to go into hospital at that point in time. If that happens you get in touch with us again, all right?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any questions? You look a bit confused.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah? OK and also you could get something called Dioralyte over the counter. So, it helps to uh, replenish your, the salts that you've been, that's lost through going to the toilet.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK? If you're a bit confused you know you can actually, uh, all this is all recorded in your app. So you can go back. I'll put that all in detail so if, you know I know sometimes it's a bit difficult to process everything, you can go back and read, read the notes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: All right then, you take care.
